title: R for Everyone: Core Programming Concepts
text:
Overview
This chapter introduces the foundational programming concepts needed to work effectively in R. You will learn how R stores data, how to control program flow, and how to write clear, reusable code.
crumbs: 2  R for Everyone: Core Programming Concepts

title: R for Everyone: Core Programming Concepts
text:
R and RStudio
R is a programming language used for data analysis and statistics.
RStudio is an integrated development environment (IDE) that makes working with R easier.






Tip



If you are new to programming, focus on learning one language at a time. Once you are comfortable with R, learning Python or another language will be much easier.



Quick Check

True or False: RStudio is a programming language.


False. R is the programming language; RStudio is the IDE.
crumbs: 2  R for Everyone: Core Programming Concepts

title: R for Everyone: Core Programming Concepts
text:
Computer Programming and Readable Code
As programs grow, we store commands in R scripts so they can be run again and understood by others.
# This line calculates the mean of exam scores
mean(scores)






Important



Always write code for humans first, computers second.
crumbs: 2  R for Everyone: Core Programming Concepts

title: R for Everyone: Core Programming Concepts
text:
Objects in R
Objects store data in R.
blood_pressure <- 120

Naming Rules

Must start with a letter
Can include letters, numbers, _, and .
No hyphens (-)







Tip



Prefer descriptive, snake_case names like blood_pressure.




Practice

Which of the following are valid object names?

blood_pressure
bp
bloodPressure
measure-BP



Valid: blood_pressure, bp, bloodPressure
Invalid: measure-BP
crumbs: 2  R for Everyone: Core Programming Concepts

title: R for Everyone: Core Programming Concepts
text:
Vectors
Vectors store multiple values of the same type.
grades <- c(80, 95, 90, 90)

Vectorized Operations
grades + 5
All values are updated at once.


Indexing
grades[1]
grades[1:3]
grades[grades > 92]


Practice

Given:
basic_vec <- c(1, 4, 7, 3, 2)
Which indexing returns 4 7 3?


basic_vec[c(2, 3, 4)]
crumbs: 2  R for Everyone: Core Programming Concepts

title: R for Everyone: Core Programming Concepts
text:
Matrices
Matrices are two-dimensional data structures.
grades <- matrix(
  c(80, 90, 85, 85,
    90, 90, 85, 100),
  nrow = 4,
  ncol = 2
)

Indexing Matrices
grades[3:4, 1]
grades[grades[,1] >= 85, ]






Note



Matrix indexing uses matrix[row, column].
crumbs: 2  R for Everyone: Core Programming Concepts

title: R for Everyone: Core Programming Concepts
text:
Data Frames
Most real-world datasets are stored as data frames. They allow different data types across columns.






Tip



If you understand vectors and matrices, data frames will feel much more intuitive.

title: Working with Data in R: Data Frames and the Tidyverse
text:
Overview
In this chapter, we move from basic programming concepts to working with real data in R. You’ll learn how to manipulate data frames using the tidyverse, a collection of tools designed to make data analysis readable, expressive, and human-friendly.
crumbs: 3  Working with Data in R: Data Frames and the Tidyverse

title: Working with Data in R: Data Frames and the Tidyverse
text:
Data Frames
Most real-world datasets are stored as data frames.

Each row represents an observation
Each column represents a variable
Columns can be different data types

student_df

True or False: All columns in a data frame must be the same type.


False. Data frames can contain multiple column types.
crumbs: 3  Working with Data in R: Data Frames and the Tidyverse

title: Working with Data in R: Data Frames and the Tidyverse
text:
From Data Frames to Tibbles
The tidyverse introduces tibbles, a modern version of data frames.
Tibbles: - Print more cleanly - Are stricter about subsetting - Work seamlessly with tidyverse tools






Note



Some older R code expects traditional data frames and may not work with tibbles.
crumbs: 3  Working with Data in R: Data Frames and the Tidyverse

title: Working with Data in R: Data Frames and the Tidyverse
text:
The Tidyverse
The tidyverse is a collection of packages that help you “have a conversation with your data.”

Base R vs Tidyverse
# Base R
student_df[student_df$final_grade >= 90, "full_name"]

# Tidyverse
student_df %>%
  filter(final_grade >= 90) %>%
  select(full_name)






Tip



Tidyverse code often mirrors how you describe your analysis in plain English.




Practice

Which of the following uses the tidyverse approach?
a) prescriptions_df %>% filter(RXDUSE == 1) %>% select(SEQN, RXDDRUG)
b) prescriptions_df[prescriptions_df$RXDUSE == 1, c("SEQN", "RXDDRUG")]


a) uses the tidyverse approach.
crumbs: 3  Working with Data in R: Data Frames and the Tidyverse

title: Working with Data in R: Data Frames and the Tidyverse
text:
Subsetting with filter() and select()
student_df %>%
  filter(Post.Assessment.Score > Pre.Assessment.Score) %>%
  select(Name, Grade)

filter() selects rows
select() selects columns







Warning



Do not use filter() to select columns — use select().
crumbs: 3  Working with Data in R: Data Frames and the Tidyverse

title: Working with Data in R: Data Frames and the Tidyverse
section: Creating and Modifying Columns with mutate()
text:
Creating and Modifying Columns with mutate()
Use mutate() to create new variables or modify existing ones.
student_df %>%
  mutate(
    Total_Attendance =
      Week.1.Attendance +
      Week.2.Attendance +
      Week.3.Attendance +
      Week.4.Attendance +
      Week.5.Attendance
  )

Combining mutate() and filter()
student_df %>%
  mutate(Total_Attendance =
           Week.1.Attendance +
           Week.2.Attendance +
           Week.3.Attendance +
           Week.4.Attendance +
           Week.5.Attendance) %>%
  filter(
    Post.Assessment.Score > Pre.Assessment.Score,
    Total_Attendance > 2
  ) %>%
  select(Name, Grade)

True or False: You can modify existing columns with mutate().


True. mutate() can create or modify columns.
crumbs: 3  Working with Data in R: Data Frames and the Tidyverse

title: Working with Data in R: Data Frames and the Tidyverse
section: Aggregating Data with group_by() and summarize()
text:
Aggregating Data with group_by() and summarize()
Sometimes each row represents an individual, but we want group-level summaries.
student_df %>%
  group_by(Grade) %>%
  summarize(
    Students = n(),
    Average_Post_Assessment_Score = mean(Post.Assessment.Score)
  )

Key Difference

mutate() → calculations across columns
summarize() → calculations across rows


True or False: summarize() and mutate() are interchangeable.


False. They serve different purposes.
crumbs: 3  Working with Data in R: Data Frames and the Tidyverse

title: Working with Data in R: Data Frames and the Tidyverse
text:
Concatenating Data with bind_rows()
When multiple datasets have the same columns, you can combine them by rows.
student_df <- student_df_1 %>%
  bind_rows(student_df_2)






Warning



bind_rows() requires the same column structure.
crumbs: 3  Working with Data in R: Data Frames and the Tidyverse

title: Working with Data in R: Data Frames and the Tidyverse
text:
Joining Data with left_join()
Joins allow you to combine data from different sources.
student_df %>%
  left_join(assignment_students_df, by = "student_id")

Join Types

left_join()
right_join()
inner_join()
full_join()


True or False: Both tables must contain identical student_id values.


False. Missing matches will result in NA values.

Work with data frames and tibbles

Subset, transform, summarize, concatenate, and join data

These skills are essential for real-world data analysis in R.
